Wesselényi had been broken by his imprisonment, but Kossuth, partly supported by the frequent visits of Teresa Meszleny, emerged from prison unbroken. Immediately after his release Kossuth and Meszleny were married, and she remained a firm supporter of his politics. The Roman Catholic priests refused to bless the marriage as Kossuth would not convert to Meszleny's religion. Resultingly, Kossuth became a firm defender of mixed marriages.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kossuth had now become a national icon. He regained full health in January 1841 and was appointed editor of Pesti Hírlap, a new Liberal party newspaper. Notably, the government agreed to grant a licence. The paper achieved unprecedented success; soon reaching the then immense circulation of 7000 copies. A competing pro-government paper, Világ, started up but it only served to increase Kossuth's visibility and add to the general political fervour.[PARAGRAPH:2]Széchenyi, the great reformer, publicly warned Kossuth that his appeals to the passions of the people would lead the nation to revolution. Kossuth, undaunted, did not stop at the publicly reasoned reforms demanded by all Liberals: the abolition of entail, the abolition of feudal burdens and taxation of the nobles. He went on to broach the possibility of separating from Austria. By combining this nationalism with an insistence on the superiority of the Magyars to the Slavonic inhabitants of Hungary, he sowed the seeds of both the collapse of Hungary in 1849 and his own political demise.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1844, Kossuth was dismissed from Pesti Hírlap after a dispute with the proprietor over salary. It is believed that the dispute was rooted in government intrigue. Kossuth was unable to obtain permission to start his own newspaper. In a personal interview Metternich offered to take him into the government service. Kossuth refused, and spent the next three years without a regular position. He continued to agitate on behalf of both political and commercial independence for Hungary. He adopted the economic principles of List, and was the founder of a "Védegylet" society whose members consumed only Hungarian produce. He also argued for the creation of a Hungarian port at Fiume.[PARAGRAPH:2]In autumn 1847, Kossuth was able to take his final key step. Due to the support of Lajos Batthyány during a keenly fought campaign, he was elected to the new Diet as member for Pest. He proclaimed: "Now that I am a deputy, I will cease to be an agitator." He immediately became chief leader of the Extreme Liberals. Ferenc Deák was absent. Batthyány, István Széchenyi, Szemere and József Eötvös, his political rivals, felt that his personal ambition and egoism led him to assume the chief place, and to use his parliamentary position to establish himself as leader of the nation; but before his eloquence and energy all apprehensions were useless. His eloquence was of that nature, in its impassioned appeals to the strongest emotions, that it required for its full effect the highest themes and the most dramatic situations. In a time of rest, though he could never have been obscure, he would never have attained the highest power. It was therefore a necessity of his nature, perhaps unconsciously, always to drive things to a crisis.[PARAGRAPH:2]The crisis came, and he used it to the full. On March 3, 1848, shortly after the news of the revolution in Paris had arrived, in a speech of surpassing power he demanded parliamentary government for Hungary and constitutional government for the rest of Austria. He appealed to the hope of the Habsburgs, "our beloved Archduke Franz Joseph" (then 17 years old), to perpetuate the ancient glory of the dynasty by meeting half-way the aspirations of a free people. He at once became the leader of the European revolution; his speech was read aloud in the streets of Vienna to the mob by which Metternich was overthrown (March 13), and when a deputation from the Diet visited Vienna to receive the assent of Emperor Ferdinand to their petition it was Kossuth who received the chief ovation. Batthyány, who formed the first responsible government, appointed Kossuth the Minister of Finance.[PARAGRAPH:2]With amazing energy he began developing the internal resources of the country: re-establishing a separate Hungarian coinage, and using every means to increase national self-consciousness Characteristically, the new Hungarian bank notes had Kossuth's name as the most prominent inscription; making reference to "Kossuth Notes" a future byword. A new paper was started, to which was given the name of Kossuth Hírlapja, so that from the first it was Kossuth rather than the Palatine or the president of the ministry whose name was in the minds of the people associated with the new government. Much more was this the case when, in the summer, the dangers from the Croats, Serbs and the reaction at Vienna increased. In a great speech July 11 he asked that the nation should arm in self-defence, and demanded 200,000 men; amid a scene of wild enthusiasm this was granted by acclamation. When Jellachich was marching on Pest he went from town to town rousing the people to the defence of the country, and the popular force of the Honvéd was his creation. When Batthyány resigned he was appointed with Szemere to carry on the government provisionally, and at the end of September he was made President of the Committee of National Defence.[PARAGRAPH:2]From this time he was a virtual dictator. The direction of the whole government was in his hands. Without military experience, he had to control and direct the movements of armies; he was unable to keep control over the generals or to establish that military co-operation so essential to success. Artúr Görgey in particular, whose great abilities Kossuth was the first to recognize, refused obedience; the two men were very different personalities. Twice Kossuth deposed him from the command; twice he had to restore him. It would have been well if Kossuth had had something more of Görgey's calculated ruthlessness, for, as has been truly said, the revolutionary power he had seized could only be held by revolutionary means; but he was by nature soft-hearted and always merciful; though often audacious, he lacked decision in dealing with men. It has been said that he showed a want of personal courage; this is not improbable, the excess of feeling which made him so great an orator could hardly be combined with the coolness in danger required of a soldier; but no one was able, as he was, to infuse courage into others.[PARAGRAPH:2]During all the terrible winter which followed, his energy and spirit never failed him. It was he who overcame the reluctance of the army to march to the relief of Vienna; after the defeat of Schwechat, at which he was present, he sent Bern to carry on the war in Transylvania. At the end of the year, when the Austrians were approaching Pest, he asked for the mediation of Mr Stiles, the American envoy. Windisch-Grätz, however, refused all terms, and the Diet and government fled to Debrecen, Kossuth taking with him the Crown of St Stephen, the sacred emblem of the Hungarian nation. In November 1848, Emperor Ferdinand abdicated in favour of Franz Joseph. The new Emperor revoked all the concessions granted in March and outlawed Kossuth and his colleagues. In April 1849, when the Hungarians had won many successes, after sounding the army, he issued the celebrated declaration of Hungarian independence, in which he declared that "the house of Habsburg-Lorraine, perjured in the sight of God and man, had forfeited the Hungarian throne." It was a step characteristic of his love for extreme and dramatic action, but it added to the dissensions between him and those who wished only for autonomy under the old dynasty, and his enemies did not scruple to accuse him of aiming for Kingship. For the time the future form of government was left undecided, but Kossuth was appointed Regent. The hopes of ultimate success were frustrated by the intervention of Russia; all appeals to the western powers were vain, and on August 11 Kossuth abdicated in favor of Görgey, on the ground that in the last extremity the general alone could save the nation. Görgey capitulated at Világos to the Russians, who handed over the army to the Austrians. Görgey was spared at the insistence of the Russians. Reprisals were taken on the rest of the Hungarian army. Kossuth steadfastly maintained until his death that Görgey alone was responsible for the humiliation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kossuth's career was at an end. A solitary fugitive, he crossed the Turkish frontier. He was hospitably received by the Turkish authorities, who, supported by the British, refused, notwithstanding the threats of the allied emperors, to surrender him and other fugitives to Austria. In January 1849 he was removed from Vidin, where he had been kept under house arrest, to Shumla, and thence to Katahia in Asia Minor. Here he was joined by his children, who had been confined at Pozsony/Pressburg (Bratislava); his wife (a price had been set on her head) had joined him earlier, having escaped in disguise.[PARAGRAPH:2]In September 1851 he was allowed to leave Turkey on an American man-of-war. He first landed at Marseille, where he received an enthusiastic welcome from the people, but the Prince-President Louis Napoleon refused to allow him to cross France. On October 23 he landed at Southampton and spent three weeks in England, where he was generally feted. Addresses were presented to him at Southampton, Birmingham and other towns; he was officially entertained by the Lord Mayor of London; at each place he spoke eloquently in English for the Hungarian cause. The agitation had no immediate effect, but the indignation which he aroused against Russian policy had much to do with the strong anti-Russian feeling which made the Crimean War possible.[PARAGRAPH:2]From England he went to the United States of America: there his reception was equally enthusiastic, if less dignified. Gradually, his autocratic style and uncompromising outlook destroyed any real influence among the expatriate community. Other Hungarian exiles protested against his appearing to claim to be the only national hero of the revolution. Count Casimir Batthyány attacked him in The Times, and Szemere, who had been prime minister under him, published a bitter criticism of his acts and character, accusing him of arrogance, cowardice and duplicity. He soon returned to England, where he lived for eight years in close connection with Mazzini, by whom, with some misgiving, he was persuaded to join the Revolutionary Committee. Quarrels of a kind only too common among exiles followed. Hungarians were especially offended by his continuing use of the title of Regent. He watched with anxiety every opportunity of once more freeing his country from Austria. An attempt to organize a Hungarian legion during the Crimean War was stopped; but in 1859 he entered into negotiations with Napoleon III, left England for Italy, and began the organization of a Hungarian legion, which was to make a descent on the coast of Dalmatia. The Peace of Villafranca made this impossible.[PARAGRAPH:2]From then on, Kossuth remained in Italy. He refused to follow the other Hungarian patriots, who, under the lead of Deák, negotiated the 1867 Compromise (Ausgleich), and the ensuing amnesty. It is doubted whether Emperor Franz Joseph would have allowed the amnesty to extend to Kossuth. Publicly, Kossuth remained unreconciled to the house of Habsburg, and committed to a fully independent state. Though elected to the Diet of 1867, he never took his seat. He continued to remain a widely popular figure, but did not allow his name to be associated with dissent or any political cause. A law of 1879, which deprived of citizenship all Hungarians who had voluntarily been absent ten years, was a bitter blow to him. He displayed no interest in benefitting from a further amnesty in 1880.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1890, a delegation of hungarian pilgrims in Turin recorded a short patriotic speech delivered by the elderly Lajos Kossuth. The original recording on two wax cylinders for the Edison phonograph survives to this day, although barely audible due to excess playback and unsuccessful early restoration attempts. Lajos Kossuth is the earliest born person in the world who has his voice preserved.[PARAGRAPH:2]He died in Turin on the 20th of March 1894; his body was taken to Budapest, where he was buried amid the mourning of the whole nation, Mór Jókai delivering the funeral oration. A bronze statue was erected, by public subscription, in the Kerepesi Cemetery. Many regard Kossuth as Hungary's purest patriot and greatest orator.
TEXT.German: [H1]Lajos Kossuth[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regent von Ungarn[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 19. September 1802 - 20. März 1894[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Lajos Kossuth (19.09.1802 in Monok, gest. 20.03.1894 in Turin) war Politiker und ein bedeutender ungarischer Freiheitskämpfer, der sich bis zu seinem Tod für die Unabhängigkeit Ungarns von der Donaumonarchie Österreich (ab 1867 Österreich-Ungarn) einsetzte. Seit 1825 war Kossuth, beruflich Rechtsanwalt, mehrere Jahre ungarischer Landtagsabgeordneter des nationalliberalen Flügels (1825 bis 1827; 1832 bis 1836; 1847/1848). Nach seinem zweiten Landtagsmandat wurde er 1837 verhaftet und wegen Hochverrat zu Festungshaft verurteilt. Der Grund dafür war die Veröffentlichung seiner Beobachtungen zur politischen Situation. Nach seiner Haft gab Kossuth die nationalliberale Zeitung Pesti Hírlap heraus, deren Chefredakteur er war. Zu Beginn der Märzrevolution 1848 im Kaiserreich Österreich forderte er in einer am 3. März 1848 verfassten Rede die konstitutionelle Umwandlung der Monarchie sowie Verfassungen für die österreichischen Länder. Im Verlauf der Revolution radikalisierte er seine Vorstellungen bis hin zur Forderung nach Unabhängigkeit Ungarns. 1848 war er in der ersten eigenständigen ungarischen Regierung unter dem liberalen Ministerpräsident Lajos Batthyány Finanzminister und Vorsitzender des Verteidigungsausschusses. Als prägende Kraft dieser Regierung setzte er Reformen wie beispielsweise die Bauernbefreiung um. Er baute ein ungarisches Freiwilligenheer (Honvéd) gegen die Aufstände der nichtmagyarischen Volksgruppen auf, das vor allem die Kroaten unter der Führung von Josip Ban Jelacic in Schach halten sollte, die ihre eigene Unabhängigkeit in der ungarischen Reichshälfte verfolgten. Nach dem Rücktritt des österreichischen Kaisers Ferdinand I. als Folge der revolutionären Ereignisse in Österreich seit März 1848 verweigerte Ungarn dessen Nachfolger Franz Joseph I. im Dezember 1848 die ungarische Königskrone. Als der Kaiser am 7. März 1849 eine Verfassung oktroyieren wollte, kam es zum ungarischen Unabhängigkeitsaufstand gegen Österreich, bis Kossuth am 14. April 1849 die Unabhängigkeit Ungarns ausrief. Kossuth wurde zum ungarischen Reichsverweser gewählt und hatte als solcher diktatorische Vollmachten. Die ungarische Revolutionsarmee, die durch Freischaren und polnische Emigranten verstärkt wurde, konnte die einmarschierte österreichische Armee zunächst zurückdrängen. Schließlich gelang es Österreich nur mit Beistand von Russland, den ungarischen Freiheitskampf zu ersticken. Nach der Niederschlagung der ungarischen Revolution wurden 13 Generäle und Offiziere in Arad sowie der ehemalige Ministerpräsident Batthyányi am 6. Oktober 1849, dem ersten Jahrestag der zweiten Wiener Revolution, in Pest hingerichtet. Lajos Kossuth konnte ins Exil fliehen und ging zunächst ins Osmanische Reich. Nach mehreren Stationen seines Exils trat er in London den Freimaurern bei. Später folgte er Giuseppe Mazzini nach Italien, wo er seinen Kampf für (nicht nur) Ungarns Unabhängigkeit fortsetzte. Unter anderem stellte er dabei auch eine ungarische Legion auf, die unter Giuseppe Garibaldi in den oberitalienischen Unabhängigkeitskämpfen des Risorgimento gegen Österreich zu Felde zog. 1867 wurde Lajos Kossuth im Rahmen des österreichisch-ungarischen Ausgleichs amnestiert. Als Gegner dieses Ausgleichs verblieb Kossuth aber im italienischen Exil. Ohne sein Ziel zu Lebzeiten erreicht zu haben, starb er am 20. März 1894 im Alter von 91 Jahren in Turin. Kossuth erfuhr nach seinem Tod späte Rehabilitation durch Österreich. Kaiser Franz Joseph I. ließ den Leichnam feierlich nach Budapest überführen, wo er unter Anteilnahme einer großen Menschenmenge beigesetzt wurde.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Lajos Kossuth[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reggente d'Ungheria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Nato il:[\BOLD] 19 settembre 1802;[BOLD] morto il:[\BOLD] 20 marzo 1894[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kossuth nacque a Monok, un piccolo paese nella contea di Zemplen, primo di quattro figli. Suo padre era membro della bassa nobiltà, possedeva una piccola proprietà e di professione era avvocato. Sua madre educò i figli secondo un rigida disciplina luterana. Kossuth completò la sua educazione al collegio calvinista di Sárospatak e all'Università di Pest-Buda (oggi Budapest). All'età di diciannove anni entrò come praticante nello studio legale di suo padre. Kossuth era un personaggio popolare a livello locale, ed essendo stato assegnato come assistente alla contessa Szapáry, una vedova con grandi proprieta terriere, divenne suo rappresentante nell'assemblea di contea e si stabilì a Pest. Successivamente fu licenziato per aver utilizzato i fondi della proprietà per pagare debiti di gioco.[PARAGRAPH:2]Poco dopo il suo licenziamento da parte della contessa Szapáry, Kossuth fu eletto deputato per la contea di Hunyady alla Dieta Nazionale. Le Dieta, nel 1825-1827 e nel 1832-1836, si tenne a Presburgo (oggi Bratislava), all'epoca capitale d'Ungheria. Ad ogni modo solo l'alta aristocrazia poteva votare per cui Kossuth ebbe soltanto un piccolo ruolo durante i dibattiti. In quel periodo iniziò a prendere vita una battaglia volta a riaffermare l'identità nazionale ungherese ad opera di alcuni validi leader - sopprattutto Wesselényi e Széchenyi. In parte, questa era anche una battaglia per le riforme contro la stagnazione del governo centrale austriaco. I doveri di Kossuth verso la contea di Hunyady includevano anche la redazione scritta di rapporti periodici riguardanti il procedere dei lavori alla Dieta, ma il governo austriaco, temendo il dissenso popolare, impedì la pubblicazione a stampa di quei rapporti. Lo stile colto delle lettere di Kossuth fece sì, però, che queste venissero fatte circolare sotto forma di manoscritti fra gli altri nobili liberali. Costoro gli chiesero di pubblicare la sua produzione letteraria sotto forma di una gazzetta parlamentare; il che gli fornì ancora più notorietà ed influenza politica. Gli ordini dell'Ufficiale Censore bloccarono la circolazione delle stampe litografate così come la spedizione via posta del manoscritto, tuttavia alcune copie continuarono a circolare clandestinamente.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel 1836 la Dieta fu sciolta. Kossuth continuò a riportare (in forma scritta) i testi dei dibattiti delle assemblee di contea. Grazie a ciò le assemblee ottennero una pubblicità inedita e rilevanza politica a livello nazionale. Prima di allora ognuna di esse aveva solo una vaga idea di come lavorassero le altre. L'abilità di Kossuth nell'abbellire i discorsi dei liberali e dei riformatori aumentarono ancor di più l'impatto di queste lettere; il governo invano cercò di farle sparire, ed, avendo fallito, nel maggio del 1837 dispose l'arresto di Kossuth, assieme a Wesselényi ed alcuni altri, con l'accusa di alto tradimento. Dopo aver atteso per un anno in carcere a Buda il processo, Kossuth fu infine condannato ad altri quattro anni di prigione. Il duro isolamento a cui fu sottoposto minarono la sua salute, anche se gli fu permesso di leggere. Grazie ai suoi studi, migliorò la sua cultura politica, ed acquisì, grazie allo studio della Bibbia e di Shakespeare, una profonda conoscenza dell'inglese.[PARAGRAPH:2]Quegli arresti avevano causato grande indignazione: la Dieta, che fu riconvocata nel 1839, chiese il rilascio dei prigionieri, e rifiutò di approvare ogni delibera del governo. Metternich, a lungo inflessibile, a causa delle difficoltà della guerra, nel 1840 si convinse a dare ascolto alle proteste. Wesselényi uscì dal carcere completamente distrutto ma Kossuth, in parte confortato dalle frequenti visite di Teresa Meszleny, non perse le sue energie. Immediatamente dopo il rilascio, Kossuth e Meszleny si sposarono, e lei rimase sempre un valido supporto alla sua politica. Il clero della Chiesa Romana Cattolica rifiutò di benedire il matrimonio poiché Kossuth si rifiutò di convertirsi alla religione di Meszleny (come detto, era luterano). Come risultato, Kossuth divenne un fermo sostenitore dei matrimoni misti.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kossuth ora era diventato un'icona nazionale. Si ristabilì completamente dal carcere nel gennaio del 1841 e fu assunto come editore del "Pesti Hírlap", un nuovo giornale del partito liberale; sorprendentemte il governo gli concesse una licenza. Il giornale ebbe un successo senza precedenti; raggiunse immediatamente la ragguardevole quota (per allora) di 7000 copie. Un giornale filogovernativo, il "Világ", fu fondato nello stesso periodo ma ciò servì solo ad incrementare la popolarità di Kossuth e del suo fervore politico.[PARAGRAPH:2]Széchenyi, il grande riformatore, avvertì pubblicamente Kossuth che il suo appellarsi alle passioni del popolo avrebbe portato la nazione verso la rivoluzione. Kossuth, imperterrito, non si fermò dal sostenere pubblicamente le ragioni delle riforme chieste da tutti i liberali: l'abolizione dell'inalienabilita delle eredita nobiliari e dei privilegi feudali e la tassazione dei nobili. Egli fu sul punto di prendere in considerazione la possibilità di separazione dell'Ungheria dall'Austria. Combinando questo suo nazionalismo con l'insistenza ad affermare la superiorità dei magiari sugli slavi che abitavano l'Ungheria, egli piantò i semi sia del collasso dell'Ungheria nel 1849 sia della propria dipartita politica.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel 1844 Kossuth fu licenziato dal Pesti Hírlap dopo una discussione col proprietario sul suo salario. Si crede però che il litigio sia stato fomentato da intrighi governativi, tant'è che a Kossuth non fu in seguito concessa la licenza per fondare un suo giornale. In un colloquio personale, Metternich gli offrì un incarico governativo, ma Kossuth rifiutò; a causa di ciò rimase per tre anni senza lavoro. Egli continuò comunque nella sua attività di agitatore nel nome dell'indipendenza politica e commerciale dell'Ungheria. Adottò i principi economici teorizzati dal tedesco Friedrich List, e fondo la societò "Védegylet", i cui membri consumavano solo prodotti ungheresi. Cercò anche di organizzare la creazione di un porto ungherese a Fiume.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nell'autunnno del 1847, Kossuth ebbe la possibilità di mettere in pratica le sue idee. Grazie al supporto di Lajos Batthyány, nel corso di una campagna combattuta aspramente, fu eletto alla nuova Dieta come rappresentante di Pest. Egli dichiaro: «ora che sono un deputato, smettero di essere un agitatore». Immediatamente divenne il capo degli estremisti liberali, non essendo presente alla Dieta in quel periodo Ferenc Deák. Batthyány, Széchenyi, Szemere and Eötvös, i suoi rivali politici, si resero conto che le sue personali ambizioni ed il suo egoismo lo avevano portato in una posizione di preminenza, e che avrebbe usato questa posizione per assumere il controllo della nazione; ma davanti alla sua eloquenza e alla sua energia tutte le opposizioni erano inutili. Kossuth, con la sua tecnica oratoria, al fine di ottenere un risultato migliore, faceva ricorso, nel suo appellarsi alle emozioni più intense, a temi di elevato spessore etico e ad immagini dall'effetto drammatico. Ciononostante egli non ambì mai e non ottenne mai il potere assoluto. Una caratteristica della sua natura, invece, forse inconscia, era quella di condurre tutto verso la crisi.[PARAGRAPH:2]La crisi arrivò, e lui la sfruttò al massimo. Il 3 marzo 1848, appena giunta la notizia della sommossa a Parigi, chiese con forza un governo parlamentare per l'Ungheria ed un governo costituzionale per il resto dell'Austria. Egli confidava nel fatto che gli Asburgo, nella persona del "nostro amato arciduca Francesco Giuseppe" (allora diciassettenne), accettassero di perpetuare l'antica gloria della dinastia venendo incontro almeno in parte alle aspirazioni di un popolo alla libertà. Egli divenne in quel momento il leader della rivoluzione in tutta Europa; le sue parole furono lette ad alta voce nelle strade di Vienna da una folla inferocita che chiese ed ottenne il rovesciamento di Metternich (13 marzo), e quando una delegazione della Dieta giunse a Vienna per ricevere l'assenso dell'imperatore Ferdinando alle loro petizioni, le ovazioni più calorose furono per Kossuth. Batthyány, che formò il primo governo parlamentare, nominò Kossuth Ministro dell'economia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Con incredibile energia egli iniziò la sua opera di sfruttamento delle risorse interne del paese: reistituì una moneta nazionale all'Ungheria, ed usò ogni mezzo per promuovere il sentimento nazionale di appartenenza. Come caratteristica, le nuove banconote ungheresi avevano il nome di Kossuth come iscrizione più in evidenza e venivano chiamate "le banconote di Kossuth", espressione che in futuro sarebbe diventata un proverbio. Uscì alle stampe un nuovo giornale, a cui fu dato il nome di Kossuth Hírlapja, cosicché fu quello di Kossuth piuttosto che quello del Funzionario Imperiale o del Presidente dei Ministri il primo nome associato dal popolo al nuovo governo. Molto più importante fu la circostanza in cui, in estate, le minacce da parte dei croati e dei serbi nonché la reazione di Vienna aumentarono. In un grande discorso l'11 luglio, egli incitò la nazione ad armarsi per la propria difesa e chiese l'arruolamento di 200.000 uomini; tra scene di grande entusiasmo, la richiesta di Kossuth fu approvata per acclamazione. Quando il croato Josip Jelacic marciò su Pest egli andò di paese in paese per aizzare il popolo alla difesa del suolo patrio; fu così che venne creata l'armata popolare "Honvéd". Quando Batthyány si dimise, Kossuth ebbe in concomitanza con Szemere l'incarico di guidare provvisoriamente il governo, e alla fine di Settembre fu nominato Presidente del Comitato per la Difesa Nazionale. [PARAGRAPH:2]Da questo momento egli divenne virtualmente un dittatore. La direzione dell'intero governo finì nelle sue mani. Senza esperienza militare, egli dovette controllare e dirigere i movimenti delle armate; non riuscì infatti a mantenere sotto controllo i generali o a comprendere che la cooperazione militare è essenziale per il successo. Artúr Görgey in particolare, le cui grandi abilità Kossuth fu il primo ad individuare, rifiutò di obbedire; i due uomini avevano personalità molto diverse. Due volte Kossuth lo sollevò dal comando; due volte dovette reinsediarlo. Forse sarebbe stato un bene se Kossuth avesse avuto un pizzico della spietatezza calcolata di Görgey, giacché, come si vide in effetti, il potere rivoluzionario che egli aveva ottenuto sarebbe potuto essere mantenuto solo con metodi rivoluzionari; ma Kossuth era per natura di cuore teneto e clemente in ogni occasione; sebbene spesso dimostrasse audacia, gli mancò la determinatezza nel mettersi d'accordo coi suoi uomini. E' stato detto che egli si dimostrò privo di coraggio personale; questo non è improbabile, l'eccesso di focosità che fece di lui un così grande oratore difficilmente potrebbe combinarsi col sangue freddo richiesto da un soldato in caso di pericolo; tuttavia nessuno fu capace quanto lui di infondere coraggio negli altri.[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante il terribile inverno che seguì, la sua energia ed il suo spirito non si raffreddarono mai. Fu lui che vinse la riluttanza dell'esercito a marciare alla volta di Vienna; dopo la sconfitta di Schwechat (alle porte di Vienna), alla quale lui fu presente, inviò Bern come supporto nella guerra in Transilvania. Alla fine dell'anno, quando gli Austriaci stavano raggiungendo Pest, chiese la mediazione dell'inviato americano Stiles. Ciononostante il generale austriaco Windisch-Grätz rifiutò ogni trattativa, costringendo la Dieta ed il governo a fuggire a Debrecen; Kossuth portò con sé la corona di Santo Stefano, il sacro emblema della nazione ungherese. Nel novembre del 1848, l'Imperatore Ferdinando abdicò in favore di Francesco Giuseppe. Il nuovo Imperatore revocò tutte le concessioni fatte a marzo e dichiarò fuorilegge Kossuth e i suoi colleghi. In aprile, dopo che gli ungheresi ottennero alcuni successi militari grazie ad un esercito tornato in forze, Kossuth proclamò l'indipendenza ungherese con una dichiarazione ufficiale in cui veniva affermato che "la Casa degli Asburgo-Lorena, spergiura al cospetto di Dio e dell'Uomo, ha perso il trono ungherese." Questo fu un passo che evidenzia la sua predilezione per le azioni estreme e drammatiche, ma questa volta si crearono anche dei dissensi fra lui e coloro che desideravano soltanto un'autonomia di fatto sotto la vecchia dinastia; i suoi nemici, poi, non si lasciarono scappare l'occasione di accusarlo di mirare alla corona ungherese. Al momento, la futura forma di governo non era ancora stata decisa, anche se Kossuth fu dichiarato Reggente. Le speranze di successo vennero però frustrate dall'intervento della Russia; tutti gli appelli alle potenze occidentali furono vani, e l'11 agosto Kossuth abdicò in favore di Görgey, sulla base del fatto che in quella situazione estrema solo un generale avrebbe potuto salvare la nazione. Görgey a Világos si arrese ai russi, i quali consegnarono il suo esercito agli austriaci. Görgey fu risparmiato, grazie alle insistenze dei russi, ma il resto dell'esercito ungherese fu fatto oggetto di pesanti rappresaglie. Kossuth con fermezza sostenne fino alla sua morte che Görgey fu il solo responsabile per quella umiliazione.[PARAGRAPH:2]La carriera di Kossuth era al termine. Ritrovatosi ad essere un fuggiasco solitario, attraversò la frontiera turca e ricevette ospitalità dalle autorità locali, le quali, supportate dall'Inghilterra e malgrado gli accordi con gli imperatori alleati, rifiutarono di consegnare lui e gli altri fuggiaschi all'Austria. Nel gennaio del 1849 fu trasferito da Vidin (nell'odierna Bulgaria nord-occidentale), dove lui era stato tenuto agli arresti domiciliari, a Shumla, e quindi a Katahia in Asia minore. Qui si ricongiunse coi figli, che erano stati confinati a Presburgo (Bratislava); sua moglie (che aveva una taglia sulla testa) lo aveva raggiunto poco prima, essendo scappata grazie ad un travestimento.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel settembre del 1851 gli fu permesso di lasciare la Turchia a bordo di un vascello militare americano. Egli dapprima approdò a Marsiglia, dove ricevette un'accoglienza entusiastica dalla gente, ma dove il Principe-Presidente Luigi Napoleone Bonaparte rifiutò di accordargli il permesso di attraversare la Francia. Il 23 ottobre approdò a Southampton e trascorse tre settimane in Inghilterra, dove fu ancora una volta acclamato. Gli fu concesso di tenere dei discorsi a Southampton, Birmingham ed in altre citta; fu ufficialmente ospite del sindaco di Londra e in ogni occasione fece valere la sua eloquenza in inglese parlando della causa ungherese. Gli effetti di quanto disse non furono immediati, ma l'indignazione che lui riuscì a far esplodere contro la politica russa ha molti legami con i forti sentimenti anti-russi che furono alla base della guerra di Crimea.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dall'Inghilterra si trasferì negli Stati Uniti d'America: lì l'accoglienza fu ugualmente entusiastica, anche se meno "dignitosa". Gradualmente, il suo stile autocratico e alieno a compromessi distrusse ogni reale influenza all'interno della comunità di espatriati. Gli altri esuli ungheresi protestavano contro la sua apparente pretesa di essere l'unico eroe della rivoluzione. Il conte Kasimir Batthyány lo attaccò sul Times, e Szemere, che era stato primo ministro sotto la sua reggenza, pubblicò un articolo in cui criticò aspramente le sue azioni e il suo carattere, accusandolo di arroganza, codardia e ambivalenza. Kossuth ritornò presto in Inghilterra, dove visse per otto anni in stretti rapporti con Mazzini, da cui, nonostante alcuni timori, fu persuaso ad unirsi al comitato rivoluzionario. Continuarono però le frizioni fra lui e gli altri esuli ungheresi, offesi in particolar modo dal suo continuare ad utilizzare il titolo di Reggente. Kossuth teneva d'occhio con ansietà ogni opportunità di liberare una volta per tutte il suo paese dall'Austria. Un tentativo di organizzare una legione ungherese durante la guerra di Crimea fu interrotto, ma nel 1859 riuscì ad aprire dei negoziati con Napoleone III; lasciò l'Inghilterra per l'Italia ed iniziò ad organizzare un'altra legione ungherese, con la quale intendeva scendere lungo le coste della Dalmazia. La pace di Villafranca rese tutto questo impossibile.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nonostante questo episodio, Kossuth rimase in Italia. Rifiutò di seguire gli altri patrioti ungheresi, che, grazie alle trattative di Ferenc Deák, negoziarono il "Compromesso" del 1867 (Ausgleich/Kiegyezés) ed ottennero l'amnistia. E' in dubbio se l'Imperatore Francesco Giuseppe avrebbe acconsentito ad estendere l'amnistia a Kossuth. Ufficialmente, Kossuth non si riconciliò mai con la casa d'Asburgo, e si adoperò sempre per uno stato completamente independente. Sebbene eletto alla Dieta del 1867, egli non si insediò mai. Continuò a rimanere una figura molto popolare, ma il suo nome non fu più associato ad alcuna manifestazione di dissenso di qualsiasi natura politica. Una legge del 1879, che privava della cittadinanza tutti gli ungheresi che si erano volontariamente assentati dal paese per più di dieci anni, fu per lui un boccone amaro. Egli non mostrò interesse a beneficiare di un'ulteriore amnistia nel 1880.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel 1890, una delegazione di pellegrini ungheresi a Torino registrarono un piccolo messaggio patriottico dell'ormai anziano Lajos Kossuth. La registrazione originale effettuata con il fonografo di Edison esiste ancora al giorno d'oggi, sebbene scarsamente udibile a causa degli eccessivi ascolti effettuati e dei falliti tentativi di restaurazione. Lajos Kossuth e la più antica persona al mondo che abbia la sua voce ancora registrata e conservata.[PARAGRAPH:2]Morì a Torino il 20 Marzo 1894; il suo corpo è stato portato a Budapest, dove fu stato seppellito mentre nell'intera nazione fu dichiarato il lutto nazionale. Mór Jókai tenne il discorso funebre. Grazie ad una sottoscrizione pubblica, fu eretta una statua di bronzo nel cimetero di Kerepesi. Molti ricordano Kossuth come uno dei più puri patrioti d'Ungheria nonché il più grande fra gli oratori.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Lajos Kossuth[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regent of Hungary[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Kossuth was born at Monok, a small town in the county of Zemplen, the eldest of four children. His father belonged to minor nobility, had a small estate, and was an advocate by profession. His mother raised the family as strict Lutherans. Kossuth completed his education at the Calvinist college of Sárospatak and the University of Pest-Buda (now Budapest). Aged nineteen, he entered his father's legal practice. He was popular locally, and, having been appointed steward to the countess Szapary, a widow with large estates, he became her voting representative in the county assembly and settled in Pest. He was subsequently dismissed on the grounds of using estate funds to pay a gambling debt.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shortly after his dismissal by Countess Szapary, Kossuth was appointed as deputy to Count Hunyady at the National Diet. The Diet met during 18251827 and 18321836 in Pressburg, then capital of Hungary. Only the upper aristocracy could vote, however, and Kossuth took little part in the debates. At the time, a struggle to reassert a Hungarian national identity was beginning to emerge under able leaders most notably Wesselényi and the Széchenyis. In part, this was also a struggle for reform against the stagnant Austrian government. Kossuth's duties to Count Hunyady included reporting on Diet proceedings in writing, as the Austrian government, fearing popular dissent, had banned published reports. The high quality of Kossuth's letters led to their being circulated in manuscript among other Liberal magnates. Readership demands turned his output into the editing of an organized parliamentary gazette; spreading his name and influence further. Orders from the Official Censor halted circulation by lithograph printing. Distribution in manuscript by post was forbidden by the government, although circulation by hand continued.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1836 the Diet was dissolved. Kossuth continued to report (in letter form), covering the debates of the county assemblies. This new-found publicity gave the assemblies national political prominence. Previously they had had little idea of each others' proceedings. His skilful embellishment of the speeches from the Liberals and Reformers further enhanced the impact of his newsletters. The government in vain attempted to suppress the letters, and other means having failed, he was in May 1837, with Wesselényi and several others, arrested on a charge of high treason. After spending a year in prison at Buda awaiting trial, he was condemned to four more years' imprisonment. His strict confinement damaged his health, but he was allowed to read. He greatly increased his political knowledge, and also acquired, from the study of the Bible and Shakespeare, a thorough knowledge of English.[PARAGRAPH:2]The arrests had caused great indignation. The Diet, which reconvened in 1839, demanded the release of the prisoners, and refused to pass any government measures. Metternich long remained obdurate, but the danger of war in 1840 obliged him to give way. Wesselényi had been broken by his imprisonment, but Kossuth, partly supported by the frequent visits of Teresa Meszleny, emerged from prison unbroken. Immediately after his release Kossuth and Meszleny were married, and she remained a firm supporter of his politics. The Roman Catholic priests refused to bless the marriage as Kossuth would not convert to Meszleny's religion. Resultingly, Kossuth became a firm defender of mixed marriages.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kossuth had now become a national icon. He regained full health in January 1841 and was appointed editor of Pesti Hírlap, a new Liberal party newspaper. Notably, the government agreed to grant a licence. The paper achieved unprecedented success; soon reaching the then immense circulation of 7000 copies. A competing pro-government paper, Világ, started up but it only served to increase Kossuth's visibility and add to the general political fervour.[PARAGRAPH:2]Széchenyi, the great reformer, publicly warned Kossuth that his appeals to the passions of the people would lead the nation to revolution. Kossuth, undaunted, did not stop at the publicly reasoned reforms demanded by all Liberals: the abolition of entail, the abolition of feudal burdens and taxation of the nobles. He went on to broach the possibility of separating from Austria. By combining this nationalism with an insistence on the superiority of the Magyars to the Slavonic inhabitants of Hungary, he sowed the seeds of both the collapse of Hungary in 1849 and his own political demise.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1844, Kossuth was dismissed from Pesti Hírlap after a dispute with the proprietor over salary. It is believed that the dispute was rooted in government intrigue. Kossuth was unable to obtain permission to start his own newspaper. In a personal interview Metternich offered to take him into the government service. Kossuth refused, and spent the next three years without a regular position. He continued to agitate on behalf of both political and commercial independence for Hungary. He adopted the economic principles of List, and was the founder of a "Védegylet" society whose members consumed only Hungarian produce. He also argued for the creation of a Hungarian port at Fiume.[PARAGRAPH:2]In autumn 1847, Kossuth was able to take his final key step. Due to the support of Lajos Batthyány during a keenly fought campaign, he was elected to the new Diet as member for Pest. He proclaimed: "Now that I am a deputy, I will cease to be an agitator." He immediately became chief leader of the Extreme Liberals. Ferenc Deák was absent. Batthyány, István Széchenyi, Szemere and József Eötvös, his political rivals, felt that his personal ambition and egoism led him to assume the chief place, and to use his parliamentary position to establish himself as leader of the nation; but before his eloquence and energy all apprehensions were useless. His eloquence was of that nature, in its impassioned appeals to the strongest emotions, that it required for its full effect the highest themes and the most dramatic situations. In a time of rest, though he could never have been obscure, he would never have attained the highest power. It was therefore a necessity of his nature, perhaps unconsciously, always to drive things to a crisis.[PARAGRAPH:2]The crisis came, and he used it to the full. On March 3, 1848, shortly after the news of the revolution in Paris had arrived, in a speech of surpassing power he demanded parliamentary government for Hungary and constitutional government for the rest of Austria. He appealed to the hope of the Habsburgs, "our beloved Archduke Franz Joseph" (then 17 years old), to perpetuate the ancient glory of the dynasty by meeting half-way the aspirations of a free people. He at once became the leader of the European revolution; his speech was read aloud in the streets of Vienna to the mob by which Metternich was overthrown (March 13), and when a deputation from the Diet visited Vienna to receive the assent of Emperor Ferdinand to their petition it was Kossuth who received the chief ovation. Batthyány, who formed the first responsible government, appointed Kossuth the Minister of Finance.[PARAGRAPH:2]With amazing energy he began developing the internal resources of the country: re-establishing a separate Hungarian coinage, and using every means to increase national self-consciousness Characteristically, the new Hungarian bank notes had Kossuth's name as the most prominent inscription; making reference to "Kossuth Notes" a future byword. A new paper was started, to which was given the name of Kossuth Hírlapja, so that from the first it was Kossuth rather than the Palatine or the president of the ministry whose name was in the minds of the people associated with the new government. Much more was this the case when, in the summer, the dangers from the Croats, Serbs and the reaction at Vienna increased. In a great speech July 11 he asked that the nation should arm in self-defence, and demanded 200,000 men; amid a scene of wild enthusiasm this was granted by acclamation. When Jellachich was marching on Pest he went from town to town rousing the people to the defence of the country, and the popular force of the Honvéd was his creation. When Batthyány resigned he was appointed with Szemere to carry on the government provisionally, and at the end of September he was made President of the Committee of National Defence.[PARAGRAPH:2]From this time he was a virtual dictator. The direction of the whole government was in his hands. Without military experience, he had to control and direct the movements of armies; he was unable to keep control over the generals or to establish that military co-operation so essential to success. Artúr Görgey in particular, whose great abilities Kossuth was the first to recognize, refused obedience; the two men were very different personalities. Twice Kossuth deposed him from the command; twice he had to restore him. It would have been well if Kossuth had had something more of Görgey's calculated ruthlessness, for, as has been truly said, the revolutionary power he had seized could only be held by revolutionary means; but he was by nature soft-hearted and always merciful; though often audacious, he lacked decision in dealing with men. It has been said that he showed a want of personal courage; this is not improbable, the excess of feeling which made him so great an orator could hardly be combined with the coolness in danger required of a soldier; but no one was able, as he was, to infuse courage into others.[PARAGRAPH:2]During all the terrible winter which followed, his energy and spirit never failed him. It was he who overcame the reluctance of the army to march to the relief of Vienna; after the defeat of Schwechat, at which he was present, he sent Bern to carry on the war in Transylvania. At the end of the year, when the Austrians were approaching Pest, he asked for the mediation of Mr Stiles, the American envoy. Windisch-Grätz, however, refused all terms, and the Diet and government fled to Debrecen, Kossuth taking with him the Crown of St Stephen, the sacred emblem of the Hungarian nation. In November 1848, Emperor Ferdinand abdicated in favour of Franz Joseph. The new Emperor revoked all the concessions granted in March and outlawed Kossuth and his colleagues. In April 1849, when the Hungarians had won many successes, after sounding the army, he issued the celebrated declaration of Hungarian independence, in which he declared that "the house of Habsburg-Lorraine, perjured in the sight of God and man, had forfeited the Hungarian throne." It was a step characteristic of his love for extreme and dramatic action, but it added to the dissensions between him and those who wished only for autonomy under the old dynasty, and his enemies did not scruple to accuse him of aiming for Kingship. For the time the future form of government was left undecided, but Kossuth was appointed Regent. The hopes of ultimate success were frustrated by the intervention of Russia; all appeals to the western powers were vain, and on August 11 Kossuth abdicated in favor of Görgey, on the ground that in the last extremity the general alone could save the nation. Görgey capitulated at Világos to the Russians, who handed over the army to the Austrians. Görgey was spared at the insistence of the Russians. Reprisals were taken on the rest of the Hungarian army. Kossuth steadfastly maintained until his death that Görgey alone was responsible for the humiliation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kossuth's career was at an end. A solitary fugitive, he crossed the Turkish frontier. He was hospitably received by the Turkish authorities, who, supported by the British, refused, notwithstanding the threats of the allied emperors, to surrender him and other fugitives to Austria. In January 1849 he was removed from Vidin, where he had been kept under house arrest, to Shumla, and thence to Katahia in Asia Minor. Here he was joined by his children, who had been confined at Pozsony/Pressburg (Bratislava); his wife (a price had been set on her head) had joined him earlier, having escaped in disguise.[PARAGRAPH:2]In September 1851 he was allowed to leave Turkey on an American man-of-war. He first landed at Marseille, where he received an enthusiastic welcome from the people, but the Prince-President Louis Napoleon refused to allow him to cross France. On October 23 he landed at Southampton and spent three weeks in England, where he was generally feted. Addresses were presented to him at Southampton, Birmingham and other towns; he was officially entertained by the Lord Mayor of London; at each place he spoke eloquently in English for the Hungarian cause. The agitation had no immediate effect, but the indignation which he aroused against Russian policy had much to do with the strong anti-Russian feeling which made the Crimean War possible.[PARAGRAPH:2]From England he went to the United States of America: there his reception was equally enthusiastic, if less dignified. Gradually, his autocratic style and uncompromising outlook destroyed any real influence among the expatriate community. Other Hungarian exiles protested against his appearing to claim to be the only national hero of the revolution. Count Casimir Batthyány attacked him in The Times, and Szemere, who had been prime minister under him, published a bitter criticism of his acts and character, accusing him of arrogance, cowardice and duplicity. He soon returned to England, where he lived for eight years in close connection with Mazzini, by whom, with some misgiving, he was persuaded to join the Revolutionary Committee. Quarrels of a kind only too common among exiles followed. Hungarians were especially offended by his continuing use of the title of Regent. He watched with anxiety every opportunity of once more freeing his country from Austria. An attempt to organize a Hungarian legion during the Crimean War was stopped; but in 1859 he entered into negotiations with Napoleon III, left England for Italy, and began the organization of a Hungarian legion, which was to make a descent on the coast of Dalmatia. The Peace of Villafranca made this impossible.[PARAGRAPH:2]From then on, Kossuth remained in Italy. He refused to follow the other Hungarian patriots, who, under the lead of Deák, negotiated the 1867 Compromise (Ausgleich), and the ensuing amnesty. It is doubted whether Emperor Franz Joseph would have allowed the amnesty to extend to Kossuth. Publicly, Kossuth remained unreconciled to the house of Habsburg, and committed to a fully independent state. Though elected to the Diet of 1867, he never took his seat. He continued to remain a widely popular figure, but did not allow his name to be associated with dissent or any political cause. A law of 1879, which deprived of citizenship all Hungarians who had voluntarily been absent ten years, was a bitter blow to him. He displayed no interest in benefitting from a further amnesty in 1880.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1890, a delegation of hungarian pilgrims in Turin recorded a short patriotic speech delivered by the elderly Lajos Kossuth. The original recording on two wax cylinders for the Edison phonograph survives to this day, although barely audible due to excess playback and unsuccessful early restoration attempts. Lajos Kossuth is the earliest born person in the world who has his voice preserved.[PARAGRAPH:2]He died in Turin on the 20th of March 1894; his body was taken to Budapest, where he was buried amid the mourning of the whole nation, Mór Jókai delivering the funeral oration. A bronze statue was erected, by public subscription, in the Kerepesi Cemetery. Many regard Kossuth as Hungary's purest patriot and greatest orator.
TEXT.Hungarian: [H1]Kossuth Lajos[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Magyarország kormányzója[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Kossuth Monokon, egy kis zempléni községben született, egy négy gyermekes család legidõsebb gyermekeként. Az apja köznemes volt, a foglalkozása uradalmi ügyész. Édesanyja szigorú lutheránus nevelésben részesítette gyermekeit. Tanulmányait a sárospataki református gimnáziumban és a pest-budai egyetemen végezte. 1830-ban kapcsolódott be a politikai életbe a reformellenzék tagjaként. Ígéretesen induló megyei karrierjének aztán egy sikkasztási vád vetett véget. 1832 végén került a pozsonyi országgyûlésre, mint távollevõ fõrendek képviselõje. Itt szerkesztette az Országgyûlési Tudósításokat (183236).[PARAGRAPH:2]1841. januárban lett a Pesti Hírlap fõszerkesztõje, majd 1844-ben önként elhagyta a lapot. Ugyanis Landererrel - a Pesti Hírlap kiadó tulajdonosával - összetûzésbe keveredett. Kossuth a megemelkedõ elõfizetõkre hívatkozva - 60-ról 2000-re nõtt a példányszám - béremelést kért, különben felmond. Landerer nem adta meg a kért bért, így Kossuth felmondott. Kossuth ezután az õ kezdeményezésére alakult Védegylet folyóiratába, a Hetilapba írta cikkeit.[PARAGRAPH:2]A Védegylet megalapítását elõször megyei szinten - Tolnában - a Perczel fivérek kezdeményezték. A tagok arra kötelezték magukat, hogy 6 évig csak hazai fogyasztási cikkeket vásárolnak. A Védegylet 1844. október 6-ai pozsonyi alakuló gyûlésén elfogadott alapszabályai szerint a külföldi árut ki kell szorítani a hazai piacról, amelyet a honi ipar számára kell biztosítani. A Védegylet tagjai becsületszóra megfogadták, hogy tíz évig csak magyarországi árut vásárolnak: csak magyar mesterembereknél dolgoztatnak és olyan iparcikkbõl nem vesznek külföldit, amelybõl belföldit is lehet kapni. Az elnök Batthyány Kázmér, az alelnök Teleki László, az igazgató Kossuth Lajos lett. A Védegylet a hazai ipart a belsõ fogyasztás, a tudatos vásárlás útján próbálta meg fejleszteni. A Védegylet a korszak egyik legnagyobb botrányával omlott össze. Kiderült ugyanis, hogy a Védegylet kitûzõit Bécsben készítették. Még a botrány kirobbanása elõtt 1846. augusztus 20-án Kossuth bölcsen lemondott igazgatói tisztérõl: a társaság ettõl kezdve csak névleg mûködött. Az 1847 õszén megnyíló országgyûlésre követévé választották.[PARAGRAPH:2]Az 1848. februári francia forradalom hírére március 3-án az ellenzék programjának sürgõs törvénybe iktatását követelte. Döntõ szerepe volt abban, hogy az országgyûlés megszavazta a forradalmi átalakulás eredményeit rögzítõ törvényeket és a forradalom erõire támaszkodva kikényszerítette Bécs hozzájárulását. A Batthyány-kormányban pénzügyminiszter lett. 1848 tavaszán és nyarán a forradalom továbbfejlesztésének elkerülésére törekvõ kormány álláspontját képviselte ugyan, de mind szorosabb kapcsolatba lépett a forradalmi tömegek követeléseinek leginkább hangot adó radikálisokkal. Július 11-i beszédével elérte a haza védelmére szükségesnek tartott 200 ezer újonc és 42 millió Ft megajánlását. Szeptember 6-án elrendelte az elsõ magyar bankjegyek kibocsátását a védelmi szükségletek fedezésére. Szeptember 15-én javaslatára választotta meg az országgyûlés a védelem megszervezésére az Országos Honvédelmi Bizottmányt. Szeptember végén nagy sikerû toborzó körúton szólította fel az Alföld népét a haza és a jobbágy felszabadító forradalom védelmére.[PARAGRAPH:2]A Batthyány-kormány lemondásával a végrehajtó hatalom gyakorlása a Honvédelmi Bizottmányra szállt, amely Kossuthot választotta elnökévé. A szabadságharc további menetében óriási feladatokat oldott meg mind a hadsereg megszervezése, mind a nemzeti ellenállás és forradalmi helytállás gazdasági, társadalmi és politikai feltételeinek megteremtésében. Döntõ része volt abban, hogy az arisztokraták árulása és az 1848 végén, illetve 1849 elején a liberális nemesség soraiban is elharapódzó megalkuvás, amelyet a Békepárt képviselt, nem tudott úrrá lenni a forradalmi erõkön. Kezdeményezésére mondta ki Debrecenben az országgyûlés 1849. április 14-én a Függetlenségi Nyilatkozatban a Habsburg-ház trónfosztását. Kossuthot ugyanakkor ideiglenes államfõvé, kormányzó-elnökké választották. A szabadságharc végsõ szakaszában felismerte, hogy új intézkedések lennének szükségesek a magyarországi nem magyar népek nemzeti jogainak biztosítására. Végül is nem tudott úrrá lenni az ingadozáson, amely a cári beavatkozás és a hadihelyzet romlása után a vezetõ réteget mindjobban hatalmába kerítette. Haditudományokban való képzetlensége következtében nem ismerte fel a helyzet súlyosságát. 1849. augusztus 11-én kénytelen volt átadni a hatalmat Görgeynek, aki röviddel ezután mivel a nagyobb áldozattal járó további harc értelmetlenné vált letette a fegyvert.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ezután több ezer társával és az államkincstárral török földre menekült. Magával vitte a koronát is, melyet Orsovánál elásott. Néhány hónapot a mai Bulgária területén (Vidinben és Sumlában) töltött, majd szûkebb környezetével együtt a kis-ázsiai Kitahiába internálták. Itt készítette el a Magyarország belsõ berendezkedésének föderalisztikus átszervezésére, a nemzetiségek önkormányzatának messzemenõ biztosítására irányuló kiutahiai alkotmánytervet (1851). 1851-ben Angliába utazott, ahol a tömegek nagy ünneplésben részesítették, akárcsak 185152-i amerikai útján is. 1852 nyarán visszatért Angliába és családostul Londonban telepedett le. Kapcsolatot tartott fenn a francia, olasz, orosz, német és lengyel jobbára kispolgári emigráns körökkel, mindenekelõtt Giuseppe Mazzinival, akinek Kossuthra gyakorolt hatása megmutatkozott az 50-es évek eleji, kellõen meg nem alapozott felkelési kísérletek szervezésében. A következõ években Kossuth arra számított, hogy a nagyhatalmak közötti konfliktus teszi lehetõvé Magyarország felszabadítását; ezért összeköttetésbe lépett III. Napóleonnal. Mikor az 1859-i osztrákolaszfrancia háború elõkészítése idején III. Napóleon és Camillo Cavour szárdpiemonti miniszterelnök kilátásba helyezték Magyarország felszabadításának elõsegítését, Kossuth Lajos megalapította a Magyar Nemzeti Igazgatóságot Teleki Lászlóval és Klapka Györggyel és megindította a Magyar Légió szervezését. Miután III. Napóleon fényes solferinói gyõzelme után váratlanul békét kötött Ausztriával, mind egyértelmûbben a függetlenségükért küzdõ elnyomott népek mozgalmával kívánta összekapcsolni Magyarország felszabadítását.[PARAGRAPH:2]1894 márciusában halt meg hosszú betegeskedés után.

TEXT.English: [H1]Matthias Corvinus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Hungary[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] February 23, 1443 - April 6, 1490[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Matthias Corvinus was born in Klausenburg, Transylvania, and was the second son of John Hunyadi. After the death of Mathias's father, there was a struggle between Hungary's various barons and its Habsburg King. The gentry and the people of Pest finally came out in support of Matthias as king, while most barons also agreed to support him. [PARAGRAPH: 1] On January 20, 1458, Matthias was elected king by the Diet. At this time, he was the hostage of the king of Bohemia who released under the condition of marrying his daughter. Matthias was finally crowned after several wars with Bohemia and the new Emperor Frederick III gave him the Holy Crown. Only the age of 15, Matthias began his reign by building public health, education, and a new legal system. Matthias was also a fan of art and culture, as many artists were present in his court. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Matthias gained independence by dividing the barons and raising a large royal army. At this time, Hungary reached its greatest territorial extent of the era. Matthias was victorious in several campaigns against the Ottoman Empire by raising the Kingdom of Hungary to be a world power. After that, Matthias was intent in conquering large parts of the Holy Roman Empire. By the end of his reign, he was in control of places such as Moravia, Silesia, Lusatia, half of Austria, and Vienna. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Although Vlad III Dracula, Prince of Wallachia, had many successes against the Ottoman Empire, Matthias imprisoned him after a disagreement between the two rulers. Hungary decided to help Dracula in his fight of the threatening Ottomans, but he was assassinated. This was a major blow to the position of Hungary. In 1467, a conflict arose between Matthias and the Moldavian Prince Stephen III, after he became worn out by Hungary's policies and their presence at Kilia. A revenge lead by Stephen leads to the defeat of Matthias at the Battle of Baia. Matthias died in 1490 in Vienna, Austria, and his empire collapsed after his death because of the fact that his son was not accepted as king.
TEXT.French: [H1]Matthias Corvin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Roi de Hongrie[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates :[\BOLD] 23 Fvrier 1443 - 6 Avril 1490[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Matthias Ier est n en Klausenburg, Transylvanie, qui tait le deuxime fils de Jean Hunyadi. Aprs la mort du pre de Mathias, il y avait une lutte entre les diffrents barons de la Hongrie et de ses Habsbourg Roi. La noblesse et le peuple de Pest enfin venue l'appui de Matthias comme roi, tandis que la plupart des barons galement accept de le soutenir. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Le 20 janvier 1458, Matthias a t lu roi par la Dite. ce moment, il tait l'otage du roi de Boehme qui relch la condition de marier sa fille. Matthias a finalement t couronn aprs plusieurs guerres avec la Bohme et le nouvel empereur Frdric III lui a donn la Sainte Couronne. Seul l'ge de 15, Matthias a commenc son rgne par la construction de sant publique, d'ducation, et d'un nouveau systme juridique. Matthias a galement t un fan de l'art et la culture, comme de nombreux artistes taient prsents dans sa cour. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Matthias accd l'indpendance en divisant les barons et d'lever une grande arme royale. cette poque, la Hongrie a atteint sa plus grande tendue territoriale de l'poque. Matthias a t victorieuse dans plusieurs campagnes contre l'Empire ottoman en levant le royaume de la Hongrie d'tre une puissance mondiale. Aprs cela, Matthias tait rsolu conqurir une grande partie du Saint Empire romain germanique. la fin de son rgne, il tait dans le contrle des lieux tels que la Moravie, Silsie, Lusace, la moiti de l'Autriche, et Vienne. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Bien que Vlad III Dracula, le Prince de la Valachie, de nombreux succs contre l'Empire ottoman, Matthias lui emprisonn aprs un dsaccord entre les deux dirigeants. La Hongrie a dcid d'aider Dracula dans son combat de la menace Ottomans, mais a t assassin. Ce fut un grand coup port la position de la Hongrie. En 1467, un conflit a clat entre Matthias et le Prince moldave tienne III, aprs avoir us il est devenu par la Hongrie de la politique et de leur prsence Kilia. Une vengeance dirig par Stephen conduit la dfaite de Matthias la bataille de Baia. Matthias est mort en 1490 Vienne, Autriche, et son empire s'est effondr aprs sa mort en raison du fait que son fils n'a pas t accept comme roi.
TEXT.German: [H1]Matthias Corvinus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]König von Ungarn[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 23. Februar 1443 - 6. April 1490[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Matthias Corvinus war geboren im Klausenburg, Siebenbrgen, war der zweite Sohn von John Hunyadi. Nach dem Tod von Mathias Vater, es war ein Kampf zwischen den verschiedenen Barone Ungarn und seine Habsburger Knig. Die Leute und die Menschen der Pest schlielich in Untersttzung von Matthias als Knig, whrend die meisten Barone sich ferner darin einig, ihn zu untersttzen. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Am 20. Januar 1458, Matthias Knig gewhlt wurde durch die Dit. Zu dieser Zeit war er der Geisel des Knigs von Bhme, die unter der Bedingung der Heirat seiner Tochter. Matthias gekrnt wurde schlielich nach mehreren Kriegen mit Bhmen und der neue Kaiser Friedrich III gab ihm die Heilige Krone. Erst im Alter von 15, Matthias begann seine Herrschaft durch den Aufbau der ffentlichen Gesundheit, Bildung, und eine neue Rechtsordnung. Matthias war auch ein Fan von Kunst und Kultur, wie viele Knstler waren anwesend in seinem Gericht. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Matthias Unabhngigkeit, indem man die Freiherren und damit eine groe knigliche Armee. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt, Ungarn erreichte seine grte territoriale Ausma der ra. Matthias siegte in mehreren Kampagnen gegen das Osmanische Reich durch die Anhebung des Knigreichs Ungarn zu einer Welt. Danach, Matthias wurde in der Absicht erobert groe Teile des Heiligen Rmischen Reiches. Nach dem Ende seiner Regierungszeit, er war bei der Kontrolle von Orten wie Mhren, Schlesien, der Lausitz, die Hlfte von sterreich, und Wien. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Obwohl Vlad III Dracula, Frst der Walachei, hatte viele Erfolge gegen das Osmanische Reich, Matthias inhaftierten ihn nach einem Streit zwischen den beiden Herrscher. Ungarn beschlossen zu helfen Dracula in seinem Kampf der Osmanen bedroht, sondern ermordet wurde. Dies war ein wichtiger Schlag gegen die Position der Ungarn. In 1467, entstand ein Konflikt zwischen Matthias und der moldauischen Prinzen Stefan, nachdem er getragen von Ungarn die Politik und ihre Prsenz an Kilia. Eine Rache der Leitung von Stephen fhrt zur Niederlage von Matthias in der Schlacht von Baia. Matthias starb 1490 in Wien, sterreich, und sein Imperium nach seinem Tod aufgrund der Tatsache, dass sein Sohn nicht als Knig.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Mattia Corvino[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Re di Ungheria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita:[\BOLD] 23 Febbraio 1443 - 6 Aprile 1490[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Informazioni:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Matthias Corvinus nato a Klausenburg, Transilvania, che era il secondo figlio di Giovanni Hunyadi. Dopo la morte del padre di Mathias, c' stata una lotta tra i vari baroni Ungheria e la sua Asburgo re. Signori e la gente di Pest, infine, uscito a sostegno di Mattia come re, mentre la maggior parte dei baroni anche concordato di sostenere lui. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Il 20 gennaio 1458, stato eletto re Matthias dalla dieta. In questo momento, stato l'ostaggio del re di Boehme, che rilasciato sotto la condizione di sposarsi con la figlia. Matthias stato finalmente coronato dopo diverse guerre con la Boemia e il nuovo imperatore Federico III diede la Santa Corona. Solo l'et di 15, Matthias ha iniziato il suo regno con la costruzione di sanit pubblica, l'istruzione, e di un nuovo sistema giuridico. Matthias stato anche un appassionato di arte e di cultura, come molti artisti erano presenti nella sua corte. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Matthias ottenuto l'indipendenza dividendo il baroni e di elevare un grande esercito reale. In questo momento, l'Ungheria ha raggiunto la sua massima estensione territoriale dell'epoca. Matthias stato vittorioso in numerose campagne contro l'impero ottomano innalzando il Regno di Ungheria di essere una potenza mondiale. Dopo di che, Matthias era intenti a conquistare gran parte del Sacro Romano Impero. Entro la fine del suo regno, stato in controllo di luoghi come Moravia, Slesia, Lusazia, la met di Austria, e Vienna. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Sebbene Vlad III Dracula, principe di Valacchia, ha avuto molti successi contro l'Impero ottomano, Matthias imprigionato lui dopo un disaccordo tra i due governanti. L'Ungheria ha deciso di aiutare Dracula nella sua lotta contro la minaccia del ottomani, ma stato assassinato. Questo stato un grande colpo per la posizione di Ungheria. Nel 1467, una sorta di conflitto tra la Moldavia e Matthias principe Stefano III, dopo che divenuto consumato da Ungheria politiche e la loro presenza a Kilia. Una vendetta piombo da Stephen porta alla sconfitta di Mattia nella battaglia di Baia. Matthias morto nel 1490 a Vienna, Austria, e il suo impero crollato dopo la sua morte a causa del fatto che suo figlio non stato accettato come re.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Matas Corvino[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Rey de Hungra[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 23 de Febrero de 1443 - 6 de Abril de 1490[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Historia:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Matthias Corvinus naci en Klausenburg, Transilvania, que fue el segundo hijo de Juan Hunyadi. Despus de la muerte del padre de Matas, hubo una lucha entre los diferentes barones de Hungra y su Habsburg Rey. La aristocracia y el pueblo de las plagas y finalmente sali en apoyo de Matthias como rey, mientras que la mayora de los barones tambin estuvo de acuerdo en apoyo de l. [PARAGRAPH: 1] El 20 de Enero, 1458, Matas fue elegido rey por la Dieta. En este momento, l era el rehn del rey de Boehme que liberados con la condicin de casarse con su hija. Matthias finalmente fue coronado despus de varias guerras con Bohemia y el nuevo emperador Federico III le dio la Santa Corona. Slo la edad de 15, Matthias comenz su reinado mediante la construccin de la salud pblica, la educacin, y un nuevo sistema jurdico. Matthias tambin es un ventilador del arte y la cultura, como muchos artistas estuvieron presentes en su corte. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Matthias accedi a la independencia dividiendo la recaudacin de los barones y un gran ejrcito real. En este momento, Hungra alcanz su mxima extensin territorial de la poca. Matthias fue victorioso en varias campaas contra el Imperio Otomano por elevar el Reino de Hungra a ser una potencia mundial. Despus de eso, Matthias intencin era conquistar gran parte del Sacro Imperio Romano. Al final de su reinado, fue en el control de lugares como Moravia, Silesia, Lusacia, la mitad de Austria, y Viena. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Aunque Vlad III Drcula, prncipe de Valaquia, haba muchos xitos contra el Imperio Otomano, Matthias lo encarcelaron despus de un desacuerdo entre los dos gobernantes. Hungra decidi ayudar a Drcula en su lucha de la amenazando otomanos, pero fue asesinado. Esto fue un gran golpe a la posicin de Hungra. En 1467, surge un conflicto entre Matthias y el moldavo Stephen Prince III, despus de que l se convirti en llevarse a cabo por las polticas de Hungra y su presencia en Kilia. A la venganza conducir por Stephen conduce a la derrota de Matthias en la Batalla de Baia. Matthias muri en 1490 en Viena, Austria, y su imperio se derrumb despus de su muerte por el hecho de que su hijo no fue aceptado como rey.

TEXT.English: Welcome to this beautiful land, [CT_NAME]. I hope that you bring peace with you, for he who greets with a stick, will be answered with a club.
TEXT.French: Bienvenue dans ce beau pays, [CT_NAME]. J'espre que vous apporter la paix avec vous, car celui qui accueille avec un bton, et il sera rpondu dans un club.
TEXT.German: Willkommen auf dieser schnen Landschaft, [CT_NAME]. Ich hoffe, dass Sie, die Frieden mit Ihnen, fr die er begrt, die mit einem Stock, wird beantwortet mit einem Verein.
TEXT.Italian: Benvenuti in questa bella terra, [CT_NAME]. Spero che lei portare la pace con voi, per lui che saluta con un bastone, verr risposto con un club.
TEXT.Spanish: Bienvenidos a esta hermosa tierra, [CT_NAME]. Espero que lograr la paz con usted, por el que saluda con un palo, ser respondido con un club.
